== Modern industrial electrostatic precipitators == [[File:Hazelwood Power Station ESP.jpg|thumb|A smokestack at coal-fired [[Hazelwood Power Station]] in [[Victoria, Australia]] emits brown smoke when its ESP is shut down]] ESPs continue to be excellent devices for control of many industrial particulate emissions, including smoke from electricity-generating utilities (coal and oil fired), salt cake collection from [[black liquor]] boilers in pulp mills, and catalyst collection from fluidized bed catalytic cracker units in oil refineries to name a few. These devices treat gas volumes from several hundred thousand [[Actual cubic feet per minute|ACFM]] to 2.5 million ACFM (1,180 m³/s) in the largest coal-fired boiler applications. For a coal-fired boiler the collection is usually performed downstream of the air preheater at about {{convert|160|°C|°F}} which provides optimal resistivity of the coal-ash particles. For some difficult applications with low-sulfur fuel hot-end units have been built operating above {{convert|370|°C|°F}}.
The original parallel plate–weighted wire design{{elucidate|date=May 2013}} has evolved as more efficient (and robust) discharge electrode designs were developed, today focusing on rigid (pipe-frame) discharge electrodes to which many sharpened spikes are attached (barbed wire), maximizing [[Corona discharge|corona]] production. Transformer-rectifier systems apply voltages of {{nowrap|50–100 [[volt|kV]]}} at relatively high current densities. Modern controls, such as an [[automatic voltage control]], minimize [[electric spark]]ing and prevent arcing (sparks are quenched within 1/2 cycle of the [[Rectiformer|TR set]]), avoiding damage to the components. Automatic plate-rapping systems and hopper-evacuation systems remove the collected particulate matter while on line, theoretically allowing ESPs to stay in continuous operation for years at a time.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}}
== Electrostatic sampling for bioaerosols == Electrostatic precipitators can be used to sample biological airborne particles or aerosol for analysis. Sampling for bioaerosols requires precipitator designs optimised with a liquid counter electrode, which can be used to sample biological particles, e.g. viruses, directly into a small liquid volume to reduce unnecessary sample dilution.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Gaspard |last=Pardon |first2=Laila |last2=Ladhani |first3=Niklas |last3=Sandstrom |first4=Wouter |last4=van der Wijngaart |title=Aerosol sampling using an electrostatic precipitator integrated with a microfluidic interface |journal=Sensors and actuators. B, Chemical |volume=212 |pages=344-352 |doi=10.1016/j.snb.2015.02.008}}</ref> See [[Bioaerosol|Bioaerosols]] for more details.
== Wet electrostatic precipitator == A wet electrostatic precipitator (WESP or wet ESP) operates with [[water vapor]] saturated air streams (100% relative humidity). WESPs are commonly used to remove liquid droplets such as sulfuric acid mist from industrial process gas streams. The WESP is also commonly used where the gases are high in moisture content, contain combustible particulate, or have particles that are sticky in nature.
The preferred and most modern type of WESP is a downflow tubular design. This design allows the collected moisture and particulate to form a moving [[slurry]] that helps to keep the collection surfaces clean. Plate style and upflow design WESPs are very unreliable and should not be used in applications where particulate is sticky in nature.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}}
== Consumer-oriented electrostatic air cleaners == [[File:Air purifier.JPG|thumb|left|upright|A portable electrostatic air cleaner marketed to consumers]] [[File:Sharp FU-888SV internal 20061020.jpg|thumb|upright|Portable electrostatic air cleaner with cover removed, showing collector plates]] Plate precipitators are commonly marketed to the public as [[air purifier]] devices or as a permanent replacement for furnace filters, but all have the undesirable attribute of being somewhat messy to clean. A negative side-effect of electrostatic precipitation devices is the potential production of toxic [[ozone]] and {{chem|link=NOx|NO|x}}{{citation needed|date=November 2018}}. However, electrostatic precipitators offer benefits over other air purifications technologies, such as [[HEPA]] filtration, which require expensive filters and can become "production sinks" for many harmful forms of bacteria.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}}
With electrostatic precipitators, if the collection plates are allowed to accumulate large amounts of particulate matter, the particles can sometimes bond so tightly to the metal plates that vigorous washing and scrubbing may be required to completely clean the collection plates. The close spacing of the plates can make thorough cleaning difficult, and the stack of plates often cannot be easily disassembled for cleaning. One solution, suggested by several manufacturers, is to wash the collector plates in a [[dishwasher]].
Some consumer precipitation filters are sold with special soak-off cleaners, where the entire plate array is removed from the precipitator and soaked in a large container overnight, to help loosen the tightly bonded [[particulates]].
A study by the [[Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation]] testing a variety of [[forced-air]] furnace filters found that ESP filters provided the best, and most cost-effective means of cleaning air using a forced-air system.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmhc-schl.gc.ca/en/co/maho/gemare/gemare_008.cfm |title=Your Furnace Filter: What A Furnace Filter Can Do For You |accessdate=2008-09-01 |publisher=[[Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514164731/http://www.cmhc-schl.gc.ca/en/co/maho/gemare/gemare_008.cfm |archivedate=2008-05-14 |df= }}</ref>
The first portable electrostatic air filter systems for homes was marketed in 1954 by Raytheon.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zSADAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA70 |title=Plug-in Filter Cleans the Air |journal=Popular Science |date=July 1954 |page=70, bottom of page}}</ref> {{-}}

{{short description|Significant bottleneck in the supply of energy resources to an economy}} {{About|energy crises in general||Oil crisis (disambiguation){{!}}Oil crisis}}
An '''energy crisis''' is any significant [[Bottleneck (production)|bottleneck]] in the supply of [[energy]] resources to an [[economy]]. In literature, it often refers to one of the energy sources used at a certain time and place, in particular those that supply [[national electricity grid]]s or those used as fuel in vehicles.
Industrial development and population growth have led to a surge in the global [[energy demand|demand for energy]] in recent years. In the 2000s, this new demand — together with [[Middle East]] tension, the falling value of the U.S. dollar, dwindling oil reserves, concerns over [[peak oil]], and [[Oil speculation|oil price speculation]] — triggered the [[2000s energy crisis]], which saw the price of oil reach an all-time high of $147.30 a barrel in 2008.
== Causes == [[File:Door paard getrokken taxi.jpg|thumb|The gasoline shortages of [[World War II]] brought about the resurgence of horse-and-wagon delivery.]] Most energy crisis have been caused by localized shortages, wars and market manipulation. Some have argued that government actions like tax hikes, nationalisation of energy companies, and regulation of the energy sector, shift supply and demand of energy away from its economic equilibrium. However, the recent historical energy crisis listed below were not caused by such factors. [[Market failure]] is possible when [[Government monopoly|monopoly]] manipulation of markets occurs. A crisis can develop due to industrial actions like [[Trade union|union]] organized [[Strike action|strikes]] and government embargoes. The cause may be [[over-consumption]], aging [[infrastructure]], [[choke point]] disruption or bottlenecks at [[oil refinery|oil refineries]] and port facilities that restrict fuel supply. An emergency may emerge during very cold winters due to increased consumption of energy.
Large fluctuations and manipulations in future [[Energy derivative|derivatives]] can have a substantial impact on price. Large investment banks control 80% of oil derivatives as of May 2012, compared to 30% only a decade ago.<ref>{{cite web|title=Behind Oil Price Rise: Peak Oil or Wall Street Speculation?|url=http://axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/Article_64370.shtml|publisher=Axis of Logic|accessdate=21 March 2012|author=F. William Engdahl|date=Mar 18, 2012}}</ref> This increase contributed to an improvement of global energy output from 117 687 TWh in 2000 to 143 851TWh in 2008.<ref>Eenergiläget in Sweden 2012 figure 49000 and 53</ref> Limitations on free trade for derivatives could reverse this trend of growth in energy production. Kuwaiti Oil Minister Hani Hussein stated that "Under the supply and demand theory, oil prices today are not justified," in an interview with Upstream.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kuwait says high oil price not justified|url=http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article1236944.ece|publisher=UpStreamOnline|accessdate=21 March 2012|author=Associated Press|date=12 March 2012}}</ref>
Pipeline failures and other accidents may cause minor interruptions to energy supplies. A crisis could possibly emerge after infrastructure damage from [[severe weather]]. Attacks by terrorists or [[militia]] on important infrastructure are a possible problem for energy consumers, with a successful strike on a [[Middle East]] facility potentially causing global shortages. Political events, for example, when governments change due to regime change, monarchy collapse, [[military occupation]], and [[Coup d'état|coup]] may disrupt oil and gas production and create shortages. Fuel shortage can also be due to the excess and useless use of the fuels.
== Historical crises == * [[1970s energy crisis]] - caused by the peaking of oil production in major industrial nations ([[Germany]], [[United States]], [[Canada]], etc.) and [[embargo]]es from other producers ** [[1973 oil crisis]] - caused by an [[OAPEC]] oil export embargo by many of the major [[Arab]] oil-producing states, in response to [[Western world|Western]] support of [[Israel]] during the [[Yom Kippur War]] ** [[1979 oil crisis]] - caused by the [[Iranian Revolution]][[Image:Gcprrets.gif|right]] * [[1990 oil price shock]] - caused by the [[Gulf War]] * The 2000–2001 [[California electricity crisis]] - Caused by [[market manipulation]] by [[Enron]] and failed [[deregulation]]; resulted in multiple large-scale [[power outage]]s * [[Fuel protests in the United Kingdom]] in 2000 were caused by a rise in the price of crude oil combined with already relatively high taxation on road fuel in the [[United Kingdom|UK]]. * [[Peak gas#North American natural gas crisis.2C 2000-2008|North American natural gas crisis]] 2000-2008 * [[2004 Argentine energy crisis]] * [[North Korea]] has had energy shortages for many years. * [[Zimbabwe]] has experienced a shortage of energy supplies for many years due to financial mismanagement. * Political riots occurring during the [[2007 Burmese anti-government protests]] were sparked by rising energy prices. [[Image:Kuwait city 1996.jpg|float|thumb|[[Kuwait]]'s [[Al Burqan Oil Field]], the world's [[List of oil fields|second largest]] [[oil field]]]] * [[2000s energy crisis]] - Since 2003, a rise in prices caused by continued global increases in petroleum demand coupled with [[peak oil|production stagnation]], the falling value of the U.S. dollar, and a myriad of other secondary causes. * [[2008 Central Asia energy crisis]], caused by abnormally cold temperatures and low water levels in an area dependent on hydroelectric power. At the same time the South African President was appeasing fears of a prolonged electricity crisis in South Africa.{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/660d00cc-d6b0-11dc-b9f4-0000779fd2ac.html |accessdate=2008-02-10 |work=Financial Times |title=Mbeki in pledge on energy crisis }} *In February 2008 the President of [[Pakistan]] announced plans to tackle energy shortages that were reaching crisis stage, despite having significant hydrocarbon reserves,.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.app.com.pk/en/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=28257&Itemid=2 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070422032256/http://www.app.com.pk/en/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=28257&Itemid=2 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-04-22 |title= Musharraf for emergency measures to overcome energy crisis |accessdate=2008-02-10 |format= |work=Associated Press of Pakistan }} </ref> In April 2010, the Pakistani government announced the [[Pakistan national energy policy]], which extended the official weekend and banned neon lights in response to a growing electricity shortage.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8637454.stm|title= Pakistan's PM announces energy policy to tackle crisis|date=April 22, 2010|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> * [[Economy of South Africa#The electrical crisis|South African electrical crisis]]. The South African crisis led to large price rises for platinum in February 2008 and reduced gold production.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nature.com/news/2008/080220/full/451877a.html |title=Energy crisis upsets platinum market|accessdate=2008-02-21 |work=[[Nature (magazine)|Nature]] }}</ref> * [[China]] experienced severe energy shortages towards the end of 2005 and again in early 2008. During the latter crisis they suffered severe damage to power networks along with diesel and coal shortages.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.isa.org/InTechTemplate.cfm?Section=Departments5&template=/ContentManagement/ContentDisplay.cfm&ContentID=68134 |title=Coal shortage has China living on the edge |accessdate=2008-03-08 |format= |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116014916/http://www.isa.org/InTechTemplate.cfm?Section=Departments5&template=%2FContentManagement%2FContentDisplay.cfm&ContentID=68134 |archivedate=2009-01-16 |df= }}</ref> Supplies of electricity in [[Guangdong]] province, the manufacturing hub of China, are predicted to fall short by an estimated 10 GW.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/oilRpt/idUKL0640101120080306?sp=true |title=China's Guangdong faces severe power shortage |accessdate=2008-03-08 |format= |work=[[Reuters]] | date=2008-03-06}}</ref> In 2011 China was forecast to have a second quarter electrical power deficit of 44.85 - 49.85 GW.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFL3E7H20ZT20110602 |title=TABLE-China power shortage forecasts by region |accessdate=2011-06-12 |format= |work=[[Reuters]] | date=2011-06-02}}</ref> *''[[The Economist]]'' predicted that in the years after 2009 the United Kingdom will suffer an energy crisis due to its commitments to reduce coal-fired power stations, its politicians' unwillingness to set up new nuclear power stations to replace those that will be de-commissioned, and unreliable sources and sources that are running out of oil and gas. It is therefore predicted that the UK may have regular blackouts like South Africa.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.economist.com/displayStory.cfm?story_id=14167834 |title=How long till the lights go out? |date=6 August 2009 |accessdate=31 August 2009 |work=The Economist}}</ref> *[[Nepal]] experienced severe energy crisis in 2015 when [[India]] created an economic blockade to Nepal. Nepal faced the shortages of various kinds of petroleum products and food materials which affected severely on Nepal's economy. * The [[Gaza electricity crisis]] is a result of the tensions between [[Hamas]], who rules the [[Gaza Strip]], and the [[Palestinian Authority]]/[[Fatah]], who rules the [[West Bank]] over custom tax revenue, funding of the Gaza Strip, and political authority. Residents receive electricity for a few hours a day on a [[rolling blackout]] schedule.<ref>[http://www.btselem.org/gaza_strip/20170117_electricity_crisis Israel cannot shirk its responsibility for Gaza’s electricity crisis], [[B'Tselem]], 16 Jan 2017</ref><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-palestinians-gaza-electricity-idUSKBN17T151 Palestinian Authority halts payments for Israeli electricity to Gaza: Israel], Reuters, 27th April 2017</ref><ref>[http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/en/originals/2016/03/gaza-solar-energy-electricity-crisis.html Gaza’s electricity crisis sheds light on gap between social classes], al-Monitor, March 2016</ref><ref name="OHCA201403">[https://www.ochaopt.org/documents/ocha_opt_electricity_factsheet_march_2014_english.pdf The humanitarian impact of Gaza’s electricity and fuel crisis] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170322142754/https://www.ochaopt.org/documents/ocha_opt_electricity_factsheet_march_2014_english.pdf |date=2017-03-22 }}, UN OCHA, March 2014</ref>
==Emerging oil shortage== {{Main article|Oil depletion|Peak oil}} “Peak oil” is the period when the maximum rate of global [[petroleum]] [[extraction of petroleum|extraction]] is reached, after which the rate of production enters terminal decline. It relates to a long-term decline in the available supply of petroleum. This, combined with increasing demand, significantly increases the worldwide prices of petroleum derived products. Most significant is the availability and price of liquid fuel for transportation.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}
The US Department of Energy in the [[Hirsch report]] indicates that “The problems associated with world oil production peaking will not be temporary, and past 'energy crisis' experience will provide relatively little guidance.”<ref>[http://www.netl.doe.gov/publications/others/pdf/Oil_Peaking_NETL.pdf DOE Hirsch Report]</ref>
===Mitigation efforts=== {{Main article|Mitigation of peak oil}} To avoid the serious [[society|social]] and [[economics|economic]] implications a global decline in oil production could entail, the 2005 Hirsch report emphasized the need to find alternatives, at least ten to twenty years before the peak, and to phase out the use of petroleum over that time. Such [[mitigation of peak oil|mitigation]] could include energy conservation, fuel substitution, and the use of unconventional oil. Because mitigation can reduce the use of traditional petroleum sources, it can also affect the timing of peak oil and the shape of the [[Hubbert curve]].
[[Energy policy]] may be reformed leading to greater [[energy intensity]], for example in [[Iran]] with the [[2007 Gas Rationing Plan in Iran]], [[Canada]] and the [[National Energy Program]] and in the USA with the ''[[Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007]]'' also called the ''[[Clean Energy Act of 2007]]''. Another mitigation measure is the setup of a cache of [[global strategic petroleum reserves|secure fuel reserves]] like the United States [[Strategic Petroleum Reserve (United States)|Strategic Petroleum Reserve]], in case of [[State of emergency|national emergency]]. [[Energy policy of China#Energy conservation|Chinese energy policy]] includes specific targets within their 5-year plans.
[[Andrew McKillop]] has been a proponent of a contract and converge model or capping scheme, to mitigate both emissions of [[greenhouse gas]]es and a peak oil crisis. The imposition of a [[carbon tax]] would have mitigating effects on an oil crisis.{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} The Oil Depletion Protocol has been developed by [[Richard Heinberg]] to implement a powerdown during a [[Hubbert Peak Theory|peak oil]] crisis. While many [[sustainable development]] and energy policy organisations have advocated reforms to [[energy development]] from the 1970s, some cater to a specific crisis in energy supply including [[Energy-Quest]] and the [[International Association for Energy Economics]]. The [[Oil Depletion Analysis Centre]] and the [[Association for the Study of Peak Oil and Gas]] examine the timing and likely effects of peak oil.
Ecologist [[William Rees (academic)|William Rees]] believes that {{cquote|To avoid a serious energy crisis in coming decades, citizens in the industrial countries should actually be urging their governments to come to international agreement on a persistent, orderly, predictable, and steepening series of oil and natural gas price hikes over the next two decades.}}
Due to a lack of political viability on the issue, government mandated fuel prices hikes are unlikely and the unresolved [[dilemma]] of fossil fuel dependence is becoming a [[wicked problem]]. A global [[soft energy path]] seems improbable, due to the [[Rebound effect (conservation)|rebound effect]]. Conclusions that the world is heading towards an unprecedented large and potentially devastating global energy crisis due to a decline in the availability of cheap oil lead to calls for a decreasing dependency on [[fossil fuel]].
Other ideas concentrate on design and development of improved, energy-efficient urban infrastructure in developing nations.<ref>{{cite web |ssrn = 1221622|title = The Urban Component of the Energy Crisis|accessdate = 2008-08-13|author = Vittorio E. Pareto, Marcos P. Pareto|format = |work = }}</ref> Government funding for alternative energy is more likely to increase during an energy crisis, so too are incentives for [[oil exploration]]. For example, funding for research into [[inertial confinement fusion]] technology increased during the 1970s.
[[Kirk Sorensen]] and others<ref name="Richard Martin">"Super Fuel: Thorium, The Green Energy Source For The Future", Macmillan, (c) 2012.</ref> have suggested that additional nuclear power plants, particularly [[liquid fluoride thorium reactor]]s have the [[energy density]] to mitigate [[global warming]] and replace the energy from [[peak oil]], [[peak coal]] and [[peak gas]]. The reactors produce electricity and heat so much of the transportation infrastructure should move over to electric vehicles. However, the high process heat of the [[molten salt reactors]] could be used to make [[liquid fuels]] from any carbon source.
==2010s oil glut== {{Main article|2010s oil glut}} Rather counterintuitively, the world economy has had to deal with the unforeseen consequences of the [[2016 oil glut|2015-2016 oil glut]] also known as [[2010s oil glut]], a major energy crisis that took many experts by surprise. This [[oversupply]] crisis started with a considerable time-lag, more than six years after the beginning of the [[Great Recession]]: "''the price of oil'' [had] ''stabilized at a relatively high level (around $100 a barrel) unlike all previous recessionary cycles since 1980 (start of First Persian Gulf War). But nothing guarantee[d] such price levels in perpetuity''".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.academia.edu/6702258/A_GCC_House_Divided_Country_Risk_Implications_of_the_Saudi-Qatari_Rift |work=Al-Hayat |location=London |title=A GCC House Divided: Country Risk Implications of the Saudi-Qatari Rift |first=M. Nicolas J. |last=Firzli |date=6 April 2014 |accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
== Social and economic effects == {{Main article|Energy economics|Renewable energy commercialization}} The [[Energy and the Macroeconomy|macroeconomic]] implications of a [[supply shock]]-induced energy crisis are large, because energy is the resource used to exploit all other resources. When [[energy market]]s fail, an energy shortage develops. Electricity consumers may experience intentionally engineered [[rolling blackout]]s during periods of insufficient supply or unexpected [[power outage]]s, regardless of the cause.
Industrialized nations are dependent on oil, and efforts to restrict the supply of oil would have an adverse effect on the economies of oil producers. For the consumer, the price of [[natural gas prices|natural gas]], [[price of petroleum|gasoline]] (petrol) and [[Diesel fuel|diesel]] for cars and other vehicles rises. An early response from stakeholders is the call for reports, investigations and commissions into the price of fuels. There are also movements towards the development of more [[sustainable urban infrastructure]].
[[Image:New Vehicle Purchase Preference.svg|thumb|right|In 2006, survey respondents in the [[United States]] were willing to pay more for a [[plug-in hybrid]] car]] [[File:Global-RE-Investment-VC-Eng.png|thumb|Global New Investments in Renewable Energy<ref name="UNEP_GT_2011">[http://www.unep.org/Renewable_Energy_Investment/ Bloomberg New Energy Finance, UNEP SEFI, Frankfurt School, Global Trends in Renewable Energy Investment 2011] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130113121745/http://www.unep.org/Renewable_Energy_Investment/ |date=2013-01-13 }}</ref>]] In the market, new technology and [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] measures become desirable for consumers seeking to decrease transport costs.<ref>{{Cite web|title = High Oil Prices Boost Energy Efficiency - Report|url = http://www.planetark.org/dailynewsstory.cfm/newsid/46675/story.htm|website = www.planetark.org|accessdate = 2015-10-26|date = January 30, 2008|last = Bergin|first = Tom}}</ref> January 30, 2008 Planet Ark. Examples include: * In 1980 [[Briggs & Stratton]] developed the first gasoline [[hybrid electric automobile]]; also are appearing [[plug-in hybrid]]s. * the growth of [[advanced biofuel]]s. * [[innovation]]s like the [[Dahon]], a folding bicycle * modernized and electrifying passenger transport * [[Railway electrification system]]s and new engines such as the [[Ganz-Mavag]] locomotive * [[variable compression ratio]] for vehicles
Other responses include the development of [[unconventional oil]] sources such as [[synthetic fuel]] from places like the [[Athabasca Oil Sands]], more [[renewable energy commercialization]] and use of [[alternative propulsion]]. There may be a [[Localism (politics)|Relocation]] trend towards [[local food]]s and possibly [[microgeneration]], [[solar thermal collector]]s and other [[green energy]] sources.
[[Tourism]] trends and [[gas-guzzler]] ownership varies with fuel costs. Energy shortages can influence public opinion on subjects from [[nuclear power plants]] to electric blankets. Building [[construction]] techniques—improved [[Building insulation|insulation]], reflective roofs, thermally efficient windows, etc.—change to reduce heating costs. {{See also|Green building|Zero-energy building}}
=== Crisis management === An electricity shortage is felt most acutely in heating, [[cooking]], and [[water supply]]. Therefore, a sustained energy crisis may become a [[humanitarian crisis]].
If an energy shortage is prolonged a [[crisis management]] phase is enforced by authorities. [[Energy audit]]s may be conducted to monitor usage. Various curfews with the intention of increasing [[energy conservation]] may be initiated to reduce consumption. For example, to conserve power during the Central Asia energy crisis, authorities in Tajikistan ordered bars and cafes to operate by candlelight.{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=18784716 |title=Crisis Looms as Bitter Cold, Blackouts Hit Tajikistan |accessdate=2008-02-10 |format= |work=[[NPR]] }}
In the worst kind of energy crisis [[energy rationing]] and fuel [[rationing]] may be incurred. [[Panic buying]] may beset outlets as awareness of shortages spread. Facilities close down to save on heating oil; and factories cut production and lay off workers. The risk of [[stagflation]] increases.

[[File:Fuel Price Protest on M6 - geograph.org.uk - 1009073.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Lorries performing a rolling roadblock in a protest on the [[M6 motorway|M6]] in 2007.]]
The '''fuel protests in the United Kingdom''' were a series of campaigns held because of the cost of rising [[petrol]] and [[diesel fuel]] prices for road vehicle use. There have been three notable campaigns amongst many other protests in the 21st century. The first major protest in 2000 was primarily led by independent truck owner-operators. One group of truck owner-operators from the South East of England formed a protest group called "TransAction" that protested at [[oil refineries]] and fuel depots in [[Essex]]. Protests and blockades of oil facilities caused widespread disruption to the supply of petroleum products. The aim of the protests was to secure a reduction in the fuel duty rate on petrol and diesel, which the government refused to enact. After the protest ended, the government did announce a freeze on fuel duties, and promised changes would be made to the way that goods vehicles were taxed, which would include the taxing of foreign vehicles operating on British roads.
Subsequent protests have not had as significant an impact but did result in [[panic buying]] in 2005 and again in 2007. The 2007 fuel protests were put together by several members of the old "TransAction group" from the South of England, reforming as "TransAction 2007". The protests of this period were not widely supported nor did they cause the same disruption as those in previous years. The 2007 protest which took place at the latter end of the year, culminated in 200–300 trucks descending on [[Central London]] with the police closing off the A40 fly-over for use as a truck park for the day. Following this, a rally was held at [[Marble Arch]]. Later in the day, a deputation went to 10 Downing Street to deliver a formal petition calling for the reduction of UK fuel duty. There were those who felt that the 2007 fuel protests were politically motivated, given that many truck owner operators and farmers would have supported the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]]. The Conservative leader [[David Cameron]] gave them his support and promised a “fair fuel stabiliser”, a proposal to limit the price of petrol that was part of the Conservative manifesto for the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 UK general election]] and was announced to be implemented following the budget of March 2011. The “fair fuel stabiliser” which was meant to lower taxes levied on fuel as the price rose and raise tax as the price fell, in fact tax will still rise as the [[Price of petroleum|oil price]] rises but the tax will be capped at the level of [[inflation]] at that time and will be applied twice a year, but when the oil price is falling then the tax can be greater than inflation. Quote from "Overview of Tax Legislation and Rates" section 3.44: "When oil prices are high, as now, fuel duty will increase by the [[retail prices index]] (RPI). However, if the oil price falls below a set trigger price on a sustained basis, the Government will increase fuel duty by RPI plus 1 penny per litre. The Government believes that a trigger price of $75 per barrel would be appropriate, and will set a final trigger price and mechanism after seeking the views of oil and gas companies and motoring groups".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cdn.hm-treasury.gov.uk/2011budget_taxation_overview.pdf |title=2011 Budget Taxation Overview |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516122556/http://cdn.hm-treasury.gov.uk/2011budget_taxation_overview.pdf |archivedate=16 May 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Background== In the United Kingdom, tax on fuel for road use is made up of two elements—[[Hydrocarbon oil duty|fuel duty]] and [[value added tax]] (VAT). Fuel duty is applied at a fixed amount per litre by fuel type, and VAT is then added as a [[percentage]] of the combined total of the cost of the fuel and the fuel duty.<ref name="bbc20000921facts">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/world/2000/world_fuel_crisis/933648.stm |title=UK fuel tax: The facts |date=29 July 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> Historically, fuel duty was increased annually, broadly in line with inflation. In 1993 the [[fuel price escalator]] was introduced by the [[Premiership of John Major|Conservatives]], justified as being designed to encourage less motor vehicle use, and thus combat [[climate change]].<ref name="bbc20041005" /> The idea was to annually increase fuel duty, initially at 3%,<ref name="bbc20000921facts" /> later rising to 5%,<ref name="bbc20000921facts" /><ref name="hansard19990309">{{cite hansard |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199899/cmhansrd/vo990309/debtext/90309-07.htm |house=[[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] |date=9 March 1999 |column=181}}</ref> above the rate of inflation.<ref name="bbc20041005" /> The [[Premiership of Tony Blair|Blair administration]] then increased the rate at which the escalator exceeded inflation to 6%.<ref name="hansard19990309" />
==2000== By 2000, tax accounted for 81.5% of the total cost of unleaded petrol, up from 72.8% in 1993.<ref name="bbc20000921facts" /> Fuel prices in the UK had risen from being amongst the cheapest in [[Europe]] to being the most expensive in the same time frame.<ref name="bbc20000921facts" /> The protesters said that higher transport costs in the UK were making it difficult for haulage industry to remain competitive.<ref name="guardian20000911looming">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/oil/story/0,,611131,00.html |title=Fuel crisis looms as pickets hit depots |date=11 September 2000 |first=Peter |last=Hetherington |author2=Ward, David |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=13 January 2008}}</ref> The worldwide price of oil had increased from [[US dollar|$]]10 to $30 a barrel,<ref name="bbc20000912privy" /> the highest level in 10 years.<ref name="bbc20000907">{{cite news |title=Petrol price rise anger |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/913614.stm |date=7 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> Drivers in the UK were now paying an average of 80 pence a litre for unleaded and 80.8p for diesel.<ref name="bbc20000907" /> The government had already abandoned the fuel tax escalator in early 2000.<ref name="bbc2000912blair24hours" />
===Timeline and effects=== [[File:Ham Hill Filling Station - geograph.org.uk - 20233.jpg|thumb|right|Ham Hill petrol station, which had run out of fuel.]] In 1999, lorry drivers had undertaken protests in [[London]] against rising fuel prices and announced their intentions for a nationwide campaign.<ref name="bbc199903 30">{{cite news |title=Truckers plan nation wide protest |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |date=30 March 1999 }}</ref> The [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] organised a day of protest on 29 July 2000 to draw attention to how fuel prices had increased under [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]], visiting town centres with petitions and distributing leaflets.<ref name="bbc20000729">{{cite news |title=Tories stage petrol protest |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |date=29 July 2000 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/857114.stm |accessdate=24 November 2007}}</ref> The Boycott the Pumps campaign, also referred to as Dump the Pumps, was organised for 1 August 2000, with motorists being urged not to visit [[filling station|petrol stations]] on that day.<ref name="bbc20000729"/> Support for the day was reported to be patchy, with forecourts in the North-West being hit the hardest, some reporting a 50% drop in business.<ref name="dt20000802">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2000/08/02/npet02.xml |title=Fuel price protest day gets limited support |date=2 August 2000 |first=Sally |last=Pook |work=The Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph News and Media Limited |accessdate=13 January 2008}}</ref>
On 8 September 2000, the [[Stanlow Refinery]] near [[Ellesmere Port]] in [[Cheshire]] was [[blockade]]d by Farmers for Action, led by [[David Handley]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Refinery hit by fuel protesters |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/915251.stm |date=8 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> Over the next few days, pickets were reported at [[Milford Haven]] and an [[oil terminal]] at [[Avonmouth]] causing some petrol stations to run out of supplies.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/917653.stm |title=Protests trigger first fuel shortages |date=9 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> On 8 September 2000, fuel protesters blockaded several facilities for a limited period and disrupted fuel supplies to [[Yorkshire]], [[North West England]], and the [[Scottish Borders]] and demanding that the government reduce fuel taxes.<ref name="guardian20000909">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk_news/story/0,,366351,00.html |title=French-style fuel protest hits Britain |first=Peter |last=Hetherington |author2=Jon Henley |date=9 September 2000 |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> Some of the protesters called for a reduction of between 15 and 26 pence per litre in duties.<ref name="guardian20001109">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/budget2000/article/0,,394889,00.html |date=9 November 2000 |title=Brown's £4.7bn to buy off protesters |first=Larry |last=Elliott |author2=White, Michael |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=13 January 2008}}</ref>
The protests spread so that on 10 September 2000 they included facilities at the Manchester Fuels Terminal, [[Kingsbury Oil Terminal]], the largest inland oil terminal, and at [[Cardiff Docks]].<ref name="bbc20000910dwindle">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/918798.stm |title=Fuel dwindles as protests spread |date=10 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> [[Panic buying]] of petrol began to close some [[petrol station]]s as motorists queued for fuel which was beginning to be [[Rationing|rationed]] and reports of garages increasing their prices substantially.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/oil/story/0,,611152,00.html |title=Panic as oil blockade bites |first=Peter |last=Hetherington |author2=Patrick Wintour |author3=Charlotte Denny |date=12 September 2000 |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> [[Rolling roadblock]]s were also reported in [[North East England]] on the [[A1 road (Great Britain)|A1]]<ref name="bbc20000910dwindle" /> and [[A55 road|A55]] roads.<ref name="guardian20000911looming" /> On 11 September 2000, the government obtained an [[Order in Council]] which was authorised by the [[Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council|Privy Council]] and [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|the Queen]] to take emergency powers under the Energy Act 1976 to ensure delivery of fuel to essential services.<ref name="bbc20000912privy">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/uk/920527.stm |date=12 September 2000 |title=Action on vital fuel supplies |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="bbc2000912blair24hours" /> By now six of the nine refineries and four oil distribution depots were subject to protests.<ref name="bbc20000910shortages">{{cite news |title=UK fuel shortages worsen |date=10 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News }}</ref>
{{Rquote|left|The campaign is against the government, it's a government taxation issue - it [the government] is not addressing what the protesters want.|[[Texaco]]|<ref name="bbc20000912" />}} By Tuesday 12 September 2000, 3,000 petrol stations were reported to be closed due to a lack of fuel.<ref name="bbc20000912" /> There were also reports that there would be no fuel left within 48 hours.<ref name="bbc20000912" /> [[Tony Blair]], the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] put the oil companies under pressure to resume deliveries. [[BP]] said that they would resume deliveries if police escorts were given to the [[Tank truck|tankers]].<ref name="bbc20000912">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/921903.stm |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |date=12 September 2000 |accessdate=27 December 2007 |title=Blair turns heat on oil industry}}</ref> Tony Blair had been in contact with the oil companies during the day and announced that supplies would be back to normal within 24 hours,<ref name="bbc2000912blair24hours">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/uk_politics/922083.stm |title=Crisis 'to end in 24 hours' - Blair |date=12 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> with the oil companies having been ordered under the government's powers to commence deliveries to the emergency services.<ref name="bbc20000913tankers" /> At the same time [[BBC News]] reported that the government's [[Civil Contingencies Committee|COBRA]] committee had drawn up plans to deal with the crisis, including using the [[British military|military]] to assist in moving supplies and restricting the sale of fuel.<ref name="bbc20000913tankers" /> [[South West Trains]] were reported to be reducing some of their services to preserve fuel supplies.<ref name="bbc20000912" /> Deliberately slow-moving convoys of lorries caused traffic jams on the [[M1 motorway|M1]] and [[M5 motorway]]s.<ref name="bbc2000913bite">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/923543.stm |title=Fuel crisis starts to bite |date=13 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref>
On 13 September 2000 the government announced that 5% of normal fuel deliveries were made, however other reports indicated that only 3.8% amounting to {{convert|5000000|l}} compared with a normal daily sale of {{convert|131000000|l}}.<ref name="guardian20000914">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/oil/story/0,,611189,00.html |title=Britain grinds to a halt as Blair's pleas are ignored |first=Patrick |last=Wintour |author2=Jamie Wilson |date=14 September 2000 |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> In [[Scotland]] only very limited supplies were being delivered for emergency use only.<ref name="guardian20000914" /> Three-quarters of petrol stations were reported to be without fuel.<ref name="bbc20000913tankers" /> Some [[NHS trust]]s cancelled non-essential operations due to staff difficulties in reaching work and [[ambulance]]s were only able to answer emergency calls in most parts of the UK. The [[National Blood Service]] reported that it was coping and blood supplies to hospitals were not under threat but said that there "were some significant problems in some parts of the country".<ref name="bbc20000913b">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/923621.stm |title=Fuel crisis brings chaos to NHS |date=12 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> The government placed the [[National Health Service]] (NHS) on red alert.<ref name="guardian20000914" /> Supermarkets began rationing food due to difficulties in getting food deliveries through<ref name="guardian20000914" /><ref name="cnn20000914">{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2000/WORLD/europe/09/14/fuel.protests.05/index.html |title=Fresh Europe fuel protests flare as others end |date=14 September 2000 |work=CNN |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> and there were reports of [[panic buying]].<ref name="bbc20000914" /> [[Sainsbury's]] warned that they would run out of food within days having seen a 50% increase in their sales over the previous two days; [[Tesco]] and [[Safeway (UK)|Safeway]] stated that they were rationing some items.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/923405.stm |title=Fuel crisis hits services |date=14 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> The [[Royal Mail]] also reported they didn't have enough fuel supplies to maintain deliveries and that schools began to close.<ref name="guardian20000914" /> The government began deploying military [[tank]]ers around the country and designated 2,000 petrol stations to receive supplies for essential services.<ref name="guardian20000914" /> Some deliveries commenced from the refineries and the [[police]] supplied escorts as required to ensure that tankers could move.<ref name="bbc20000913trickle">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/922949.stm |title=Fuel supplies trickle through |date=13 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref>
On 14 September 2000, the protests began to end.<ref name="bbc20000914">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/924329.stm |title=UK fuel blockades tumble |date=14 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> Several blockades of refineries were still in operation and the first deliveries were sent to designated distribution points under the [[emergency]] powers obtained by the government.<ref name="bbc20000914" /> Bus companies had warned that diesel stocks were running out and that services would need to be restricted to extend supplies.<ref name="bbc20000914" /> The protesters said that they were giving the government sixty days to act on the issue or they would protest further.<ref name="bbc20000914" /> A planned protest by truck drivers in London was contained by the [[Metropolitan Police]] and did not cause disruption.<ref>{{cite news |title=Protest in capital foiled but northern rush hour hit |url=https://www.theguardian.com/oil/story/0,,611198,00.html |first=Vikram |last=Dodd |date=14 September 2000 |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> A later report following an analysis of the automated counting equipment on the road network the [[Department for Environment, Transport and the Regions]] showed that at the protest's peak, 14 September, car flows on UK motorways was 39% below normal levels and on major roads 25% below.<ref name="dftreport">{{cite web |url=http://www.dft.gov.uk/stellent/groups/dft_transstats/documents/page/dft_transstats_505952.pdf |title=The effect of the fuel ‘protest’ on road traffic |first=Phil |last=Hathaway |publisher=Department for Environment, Transport and the Regions |format=PDF |accessdate=12 January 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040224182437/http://www.dft.gov.uk/stellent/groups/dft_transstats/documents/page/dft_transstats_505952.pdf |archivedate = 24 February 2004}}</ref> However, for road haulage the numbers showed a smaller decline of 13% on both motorways and major roads.<ref name="dftreport" />
By 16 September 2000, supplies were beginning to be restored, at first only to the government designated petrol stations, the number of which had risen to 3,300.<ref name="bbc20000913" /> The [[London Chamber of Commerce]] reported that the protests cost businesses £250 million a day.<ref name="bbc2000913bite1">{{cite news |title=Fuel crisis starts to bite |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/923543.stm |date=13 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> After the protests had ended the [[Institute of Directors]] estimated the cost to UK businesses at £1billion.<ref name="bbc20000917">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/928701.stm |title=Drivers kept waiting as shortages ease |date=17 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref>
The conditions which catalysed and sustained the fuel protests of 2000 can be understood in terms of [[social movement theory]], for example the existence of pre-existing social networks, capacity and resources.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1111/1467-856X.00093 | volume=5 | title=Explaining the Fuel Protests | year=2003 | journal=The British Journal of Politics and International Relations | pages=1–23 | last1 = Doherty | first1 = Brian}}</ref>
===Reaction=== During the protests the oil companies were accused of [[collusion]] with the protesters by members of the government and its advisors.<ref name="guardian20000913collusion">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/oil/story/0,,611170,00.html |title=Oil giants accused of collusion |first=Peter |last=Hetherington |author2=Charlotte Denny |date=13 September 2000 |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> It was reported that the police had kept the roads clear yet [[Tank truck|tankers]] were being kept in the depots and not delivering petrol.<ref name="guardian20000913collusion" /> The [[Transport and General Workers Union]] said that there had been incidents of intimidation against drivers of the fuel tankers.<ref name="guardian20000913collusion" /> The possibility of [[court injunction]]s against the protesters was explored by [[TotalFinaElf|TotalElfFina]] who received legal advice that it would be difficult to obtain and enforce one as there was not a named individual on which to serve the injunction.<ref name="guardian20000913collusion" /> The company also stated that even if roads were clear, delivering fuel might change the mood of the protesters which had been "amicable" and that "Getting fuel to the pumps would only solve the short-term problem and not deal with the original concerns of protesters".<ref name="guardian20000913collusion" /> The TGWU subsequently called for a [[public inquiry]] into reports of collusion between the demonstrators and the oil companies, saying that they had evidence of protestors being allowed access to the oil companies' sites without security checks and that drivers who had been willing to deliver fuel being told not to.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/930719.stm |title=Union wants inquiry into fuel protests |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |date=18 September 2000 |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref>
{{Rquote|right|Were we to yield to that pressure it would run counter to every democratic principle this country believes in, and what is more, if the government was to decide its policy on taxes in response to such behaviour, the credibility of economic policy vital to any country would be severely damaged and I will simply not allow that to happen.|Tony Blair|<ref name="bbc2000912blair24hours" />}} The government stated that they would not back down<ref name="bbc2000912blair24hours" /> in the face of protests or introduce an emergency budget.<ref name="bbc20000913tankers">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/922226.stm |title=Tankers back on UK roads |date=13 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> The government argued that the rise in prices was due to increases in the world oil market prices and not the government's fuel duty.<ref name="bbc2000912blair24hours" /> Whilst agreeing that the government could not make policy in response to the blockades, [[William Hague]], [[Leader of the Opposition]] criticised the government for having increased taxes, whilst the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] argued that the government should have responded to the protest much earlier.<ref name="bbc20000912" /> The [[Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union]] called for a reduction in fuel duties during the action.<ref name="bbc20000910shortages" />
A [[BBC]] opinion poll conducted by [[ICM Research|ICM]] of 514 people by telephone showed that the public support on 12 September 2000 for the protesters stood at 78% until the possibility of essential services being affected when it fell to 36%.<ref name="bbc20000913trickle" /> An opinion poll for the [[Daily Mail]] of 502 people showed that over three quarters thought the government had handled the crisis badly.<ref name="bbc20000913">{{cite news |title=Fuel crisis post mortem begins |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/925616.stm |date=13 September 2000 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> Two opinion polls shortly after the protests had ended showed the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] had overtaken or reached equal standing with the governing [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]].<ref name="bbc20000917" /> By November support for the renewal of protests and the revival of the Conservative's fortunes had both been reduced, with Labour retaking a poll lead.<ref>{{cite news |title=Public backs away from fuel tax protests |url=https://www.theguardian.com/oil/story/0,,611037,00.html |first=Kevin |last=Maguire |author2=White, Michael |date=7 November 2000 |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=13 January 2008}}</ref>
===Consequences=== In his [[Pre Budget Report|pre-Budget report]] of 8 November 2000, the [[Chancellor of the Exchequer|Chancellor]], [[Gordon Brown]], announced numerous changes which could ease the tax burden for motorists, and which included the taxing of foreign lorries using British roads. These changes included a cut in duty on ultra-low sulphur petrol, a freeze on fuel duty for other grades of fuel until at least April 2002 (effectively ending the fuel duty escalator), placing more vehicles into the lower [[vehicle excise duty]] (VED) band, an average cut of more than 50% on VED for lorries, and a ''Brit Disc'' [[Vignette (road tax)|vignette]] scheme requiring all lorries, including those from overseas, to pay [[tax]] to use British roads.<ref name="guardian20001109" /><ref>{{cite news |title=Chancellor freezes fuel in cautious pre-Budget |work=The Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph News and Media Limited |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2000/11/08/cnbud08.xml |date=8 November 2000 |accessdate=13 January 2008}}</ref> The fuel duty freeze has been estimated to have cost the [[HM Treasury|Treasury]] £2billion pounds annually in a 2004 report by the [[Economic and Social Research Council]].<ref name="bbc20041005">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/3716346.stm |title=Fuel protest costs treasury £2bn yearly |first=Roger |last=Harrabin |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |date=5 October 2004 |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref>
A renewed protest that same month, involving a [[convoy]] from North East England to London, did not produce the same level of support or disruption as before.<ref name="bbc20001110">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1016421.stm |date=10 November 2000 |title=Fuel protesters face exclusion zone |work=BBC News |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=13 January 2008}}</ref><ref name="bbc20001113">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1020989.stm |date=13 November 2000 |title=Fuel convoy rolls on |work=BBC News |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=13 January 2008}}</ref> It ended with a protest in [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]] and the closure of the [[Westway (London)|Westway]] by vehicles left parked on it.<ref name="guardian20001115">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/oil/story/0,,611129,00.html |title=Fuel protest crawls into London |first=Angelique |last=Chrisafis |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |date=15 November 2000 |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> A similar protest from [[John O'Groats]] to [[Edinburgh]] resulted in around 80 vehicles congregating in the centre of the Scottish capital.<ref name="guardian20001115" /> There had been some panic buying of petrol due to this protest and there were temporary closures of some petrol stations.<ref>{{cite news |title=Panic buying starts despite appeals |first=Peter |last=Hetherington |author2=Maguire, Kevin |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |date=4 November 2000 }}</ref>
[[Brynle Williams]] who was one of the organisers of the protests later became a member of the [[Welsh Assembly]] for the Conservative party.<ref>{{cite news |title=Wales: First Minister's Questions (05/10/04) |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/bbc_parliament/3723806.stm |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |date=7 October 2004 |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/3698015.stm |title=Fuel prices an issue in the 2004 elections |date=5 December 2004 |work=BBC News |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=13 January 2008}}</ref>
==2005== In August 2005, petrol increased in price to record highs of over 90 pence,<ref name="bbc20050905">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/4215346.stm |title=UK petrol prices continue to rise |date=5 September 2005 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> with a small number of stations charging over £1 a litre.<ref>{{cite news |title=Further fuel protests threatened |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |date=7 September 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4221296.stm |accessdate=24 November 2007}}</ref> In September the average price had reached 94.6p a litre,<ref name="bbc20050905" /> with the rise being partially blamed on decreased world supply after [[Hurricane Katrina]] caused damage to some oil facilities in the [[United States|United States of America]].<ref name="guardian20050908">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2005/sep/08/politics |title=Protesters threaten to blockade oil refineries |first=Martin |last=Wainwright |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |date=8 September 2005 |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref>
The [[BBC]] reported on 7 September 2005 that the group responsible for the blockades in September 2000 was threatening to stage protests at oil refineries from 0600 [[British Summer Time|BST]] on 14 September 2005 unless reductions in fuel duty were made.<ref name="bbc20050907">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4221296.stm |title=Further fuel protests threatened |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |date=14 September 2005 |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> Newspapers reported that on 10 September 2005, the government had drawn up contingency plans to maintain the supply of fuel, including using 1000 army drivers to operate tankers, introducing fuel rationing<ref name="scotsman20050911">{{cite news |title=Fuel crisis: drivers face rationing |first=Brian |last=Brady |publisher=Johnston Press plc |work=The Scotsman |date=11 September 2005 |url=http://news.scotsman.com/index.cfm?id=1921402005 |accessdate=24 November 2007}}</ref> and confiscating the driving licences of those who broke the law.<ref name="bbc20050914">{{cite news |title=Relief after few attend protests |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |date=14 September 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4243950.stm |accessdate=24 November 2007}}</ref> Panic buying was reported on 13 September 2005 as drivers stocked up on fuel with drivers reported to be waiting an hour to fill their vehicles with petrol.<ref name="guardian20050914">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/oil/story/0,,1568678,00.html |title=Panic buying begins as motorists fear petrol blockades |first=Sandra |last=Laville |author2=Vikram Dodd |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |date=14 September 2005 |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> At its height, around 3,000 petrol stations were emptied of fuel.<ref name="times20050914">{{cite news |title=Petrol protest fails to ignite |first=Sam |last=Knight |publisher=Times Newspapers |work=Times Online |date=14 September 2005 |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2-1780144,00.html |accessdate=24 November 2007 | location=London}}</ref>
However, on 14 September 2005, only a small number of protesters arrived at the refineries with no intention to start blockading the entrances. The UK Petroleum Industry Association said the day's protest had proved "thankfully amazingly quiet",<ref name="men20050914">{{cite news |first=Clarissa |last=Satchell |title=What petrol demo? |work=Manchester Evening News |publisher=M.E.N. Media |date=14 September 2005 |url=http://www.manchesteronline.co.uk/men/news/s/173/173974_what_petrol_demo.html |accessdate=24 November 2007}}</ref> with the largest event attended by People's Fuel Lobby leader Andrew Spence, attracting just 10 protesters at its peak.<ref name="mirror20050915">{{cite news |title=Protest? what protest? |first=Paul |last=Byrne |author2=Jeremy Armstrong |publisher=MGN Ltd |work=The Mirror |date=15 September 2005 |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/tm_objectid=16131551&method=full&siteid=94762&headline=protest--what-protest---name_page.html |accessdate=24 November 2007}}</ref> At the [[Stanlow Refinery]], which was blockaded in 2000 only two protesters attended the demonstration.<ref>{{cite news |title=Two join in 'damp squib' fuel protest |first=Sam |last=Lister |work=Liverpool Echo |publisher=Trinity Mirror North West & North Wales Limited |date=15 September 2005 |url=http://icliverpool.icnetwork.co.uk/0100news/0100regionalnews/tm_objectid=16132361&method=full&siteid=50061&headline=two-join-in--damp-squib--fuel-protest-name_page.html |accessdate=24 November 2007}}</ref> Further protests on 16 September 2005 occurred on the [[M4 motorway]] where lorries drove as slow as {{convert|15|mph}}.<ref name="guardian20050917">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/oil/story/0,,1572106,00.html |title=Fuel protesters defy police as convoy crawl jams motorway |first=Steven |last=Morris |date=17 September 2005 |work=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref>
In responding to the protests, the government argued that lower than needed supplies by [[OPEC]] and the Katrina hurricane had a more significant impact on the price of fuel than the level of duty.<ref name="guardian20050917" />
==2007== Towards the end of 2007, fuel prices exceeded [[Pound sterling|£1]] per litre with a 2 pence rise in fuel tax in October, resulting in the highest diesel prices and the fourth highest for petrol in Europe.<ref name="bbc20071214">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7145006.stm |title=Keep to law, fuel protesters told |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |date=14 December 2007 |accessdate=12 January 2008}}</ref> New protests were planned by two unconnected groups, one called Transaction 2007 and the [[Road Haulage Association]] (RHA).<ref name="bbc20071214" /> The [[Scotland|Scottish]] branch of the RHA proposed a rolling roadblock by around 30 vehicles, whereas Transaction 2007 intended to protest outside oil refineries.<ref name="bbc20071214" /> Whilst the rolling road block attracted 45 vehicles driving at around {{convert|40|mph}} on several motorways,<ref name="bbcscotland20071215">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/7145660.stm |title=Drivers protest over fuel costs |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2008 |date=15 December 2007}}</ref> the level of protest at oil refineries was lower than in 2000.<ref name="bbc20071215">{{cite news |title=Low turnout for fuel price demos |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News |date=15 December 2007 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7145581.stm |accessdate=15 December 2007}}</ref> One of the campaign aims of the RHA was the introduction of a fuel price regulator who would control duty during periods which was supported by [[Alex Salmond]], [[First Minister of Scotland]].<ref name="bbcscotland20071215" />

In [[science]] and [[engineering]] the study of '''high pressure''' examines its effects on materials and the design and construction of devices, such as a [[diamond anvil cell]], which can create high [[pressure]]. By ''high pressure'' is usually meant pressures of thousands (kilo[[Bar (unit)|bar]]s) or millions (megabars) of times [[atmospheric pressure]] (about 1 bar or 100,000 Pa).
==History and overview== [[Percy Williams Bridgman]] received a [[Nobel Prize]] in 1946 for advancing this area of physics by several magnitudes of pressure (400 MPa to 40,000 MPa). The list of founding fathers of this field includes also the names of [[Harry George Drickamer]], [[Tracy Hall]], Francis P. Bundy, Leonid F. Vereschagin, and [[Sergey M. Stishov]].
It was by applying high pressure as well as high [[temperature]] to [[carbon]] that man-made [[synthetic diamond|diamond]]s were first produced as well as many other interesting discoveries. Almost any material when subjected to high pressure will compact itself into a denser form, for example, [[quartz]], also called [[silica]] or [[silicon dioxide]] will first adopt a denser form known as [[coesite]], then upon application of even higher pressure, form [[stishovite]]. These two forms of silica were first discovered by high-pressure experimenters, but then found in nature at the site of a meteor impact.
Chemical bonding is likely to change under high pressure, when the P*V term in the free energy becomes comparable to the energies of typical chemical bonds – i.e. at around 100 GPa. Among the most striking changes are metallization of [[oxygen]] at 96 GPa (rendering oxygen a superconductor), and transition of [[sodium]] from a nearly-free-electron metal to a transparent insulator at ~200 GPa. At ultimately high compression, however, all materials will metallize.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/anie.200602485/abstract|title = The Chemical Imagination at Work in Very Tight Places|journal= [[Angewandte Chemie International Edition]] | doi=10.1002/anie.200602485|volume=46|pages=3620–3642}}</ref>
High-pressure experimentation has led to the discovery of the types of minerals which are believed to exist in the deep mantle of the Earth, such as [[silicate perovskite]], which is thought to make up half of the Earth's bulk, and [[post-perovskite]], which occurs at the core-mantle boundary and explains many anomalies inferred for that region.{{citation needed|date = May 2009}}
Pressure "landmarks": typical pressures reached by large-volume presses are up to 30–40 GPa, pressures that can be generated inside [[diamond anvil cell]]s are ~1000 GPa,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/2/7/e1600341|title = Terapascal static pressure generation with ultrahigh yield strength nanodiamond|publisher= ''[[Science Advances ]]''}}</ref> pressure in the center of the Earth is 364 GPa, and highest pressures ever achieved in shock waves are over 100,000 GPa.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/104/22/9172.full|title = Achieving high-density states through shock-wave loading of precompressed samples|journal= [[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]] | doi=10.1073/pnas.0608170104|volume=104|pages=9172–9177|bibcode=2007PNAS..104.9172J|pmc=1890466}}</ref>

The '''Kværner process''' or the '''Kværner carbon black and hydrogen process''' (CB&H) is a method of producing [[carbon black]] and [[hydrogen gas]] from [[hydrocarbons]] such as [[methane]], [[natural gas]] and [[biogas]]. The process was developed in the 1980s by the Norwegian engineering firm [[Kværner]], and was first commercially exploited in 1999.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.interstatetraveler.us/Reference-Bibliography/Bellona-HydrogenReport.html|title = Bellona Report 6:02, "Hydrogen - Status and possibilities" Hydrogen technologies|publisher = Bellona Foundation|website = Interstate Traveler Company|accessdate = 13 March 2014}}</ref>
== Description == [[File:Carbon-nanocones.JPG|thumb|220 px|[[Scanning electron microscope]] (SEM) image of [[Carbon nanocone|carbon nanocones]] (maximum diameter ~1 μm) produced by pyrolysis of [[crude oil]] in the Kvaerner process.<ref name="nanocones">{{Cite journal|title = Carbon nanocones: wall structure and morphology|date = 29 December 2009|doi = 10.1088/1468-6996/10/6/065002|first = Stine Nalum|last = Naess|first2 = Arnljot|last2 = Elgsaeter|first3 = Geir|first4 = Kenneth D.|last3 = Helgesen|last4 = Knudsen|journal = Science and Technology of Advanced Materials|volume = 10|issue = 6|pmc=5074450|pmid=27877312|page=065002}}</ref>]] The [[endothermic reaction]] separates hydrocarbons into carbon and hydrogen in a [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] burner at around 1600 °C.
:<chem>C_\mathit{n}H_\mathit{m} -> {\mathit{n}C} + \frac\mathit{m}{2} H2</chem>
In comparison to other reformation methods such as [[steam reforming]] and [[partial oxidation]] the natural gas is efficiently and completely transformed into pure carbon and hydrogen. Of the available energy of the feed, approximately 48% is contained in the hydrogen, 40% is contained in [[activated carbon]] and 10% in superheated steam.{{Citation needed|date=March 2014|reason = Claims for high efficiency and percentage yields of products unsupported.}}<ref>[https://www.hfpeurope.org/infotools/energyinfos__e/hydrogen/main03.html hfpeurope.org]{{dead link|date=March 2014}}</ref><!--Previously tagged as "secure page, not accesible"-->
==Plasma variation== A variation of this process using [[plasma arc waste disposal]] was presented in 2009. Methane and natural gas is converted to hydrogen, heat and carbon using a plasma converter.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://fuelcellsworks.com/news/2009/10/12/hydrogen-breakthrough-for-norwegian-company/|title = Hydrogen Breakthrough for Norwegian company|accessdate = 13 March 2014|date = 12 October 2009|website = FuelCellsWorks}}</ref>

[[File:LED Dazzler cross-sect.gif|thumb|300px|Cross-sectional diagram of the "Incapacitator", from a [[Department of Homeland Security|DHS]] newsletter]] The '''Light Emitting Diode (LED) Incapacitator''' is a weapon designed like a [[flashlight]]. It emits an extremely bright, rapid, and well-focused series of 'differently-colored random pulses.' Before the human eyes can focus in on one frequency, another frequency comes on, causing [[intracranial pressure]], which results in [[headaches]], nausea, vomiting, disorientation, irritability, and visual impairment to the target (opponent).{{cite web |url=http://www.homelandsecurity.org/snapshots/newsletter/2007-07.htm#sick |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080723110013/http://www.homelandsecurity.org/snapshots/newsletter/2007-07.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-07-23 |title=Enough to Make You Sick |accessdate=2007-08-08 |date=July 2007 |work=S&T Snapshots |publisher=Department of Homeland Security: Science and Technology Directorate}}{{cite news |title=Flashlight Weapon Makes Targets Throw Up |quote=The Homeland Security Department is aiming to arm federal agents with a light-saber-type weapon that emits a dazzling strobe capable of subduing criminals, terrorists and even unruly airline passengers.}}{{cite news|first=Larry |last=Altman |title=Torrance firm sees the nonlethal 'light' |url=http://www.dailybreeze.com/news/articles/9029527.html?page=1&c=y |work=DailyBreeze.com |last=Patel-Predd |title=The Incapacitating Flashlight: DHS Is Developing an LED Flashlight That Makes Culprits Vomit |url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=3450394&page=1 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831001437/http://www.abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=3450394&page=1 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=31 August 2007 |work=ABC News: Technology & Science |publisher=ABCNews Internet Ventures |date=6 August 2007 |accessdate=2007-08-08 |df= }} The non-lethal weapon is intended as a means of protection by law enforcement officials such as police and border patrols. The light emitted is capable of rendering opponents temporarily blind so that they can be subdued more easily. ==Description== According to the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]], the weapon works:
"By simultaneously overwhelming the subject both physiologically (temporarily blinding him) and psychophysically (disorienting him). A built-in range finder measures the distance to the nearest pair of eyeballs. Then, a “governor” sets the output and pulse train (a series of pulses and rests) to a level, frequency, and duration that are effective, but safe. The colors and pulses continuously change, leaving no time for the brain or eyes to adapt. After a few minutes, the effects wear off."
The manufacturer, Intelligent Optical Systems (IOS), was awarded an $800,000.00 contract by the United States [[Department of Homeland Security]]'s Small Business Innovation Research Office. As of August, 2007, the first phase of the contract, which called for the development of a prototype, has been completed. Later phases involve the testing of the prototype by the Institute of Nonlethal Defense at [[Pennsylvania State University]], and the development of a production version, planned to be more compact and easier to carry. Bob Lieberman, president of IOS, said he envisions the device being used in "confrontations at border crossings with suspected illegal aliens or drug runners" among other possibilities. Projected users include "air marshals, border patrol agents, other officers with the Transportation Security Administration and customs officers" according to Gerald Kirwin of IOS. "In that few seconds, the officer has a tactical advantage and will actually close in to subdue or control the potential adversary," Lieberman said. The device can be used from ranges of up to 30 feet, while other non-lethal devices require an officer to approach the target much more closely, according to Lieberman. Glenn Shwaery, a researcher in nonlethal technology at the [[University of New Hampshire]], says "If you disorient or distract somebody and cause them to look away, then they can't focus on their task, which could be aiming a weapon at someone, or looking at a screen with sensitive information, or dialing a phone." Shwaery says that an LED-based device could be safer than a laser-based device intended to achieve the same effects "Getting an eye-safe wavelength with a laser has been very difficult." Shwaery says that the presence of a range-finder and circuitry to modify the intensity of the light depending on the range in the LED device increases its safety. "The ideal goal for nonlethal technologies is that they be scalable." It was intended to be released to police, border patrol agents and National Guardsmen by 2010. ==Deficiencies== Some test subjects have been completely unaffected by the light, and although the manufacturer makes claims about the product's effectiveness, the CEO of Intelligent Optics, the producer of the device, has commented "I don’t think we've had anyone actually be sick." There is debate over how well the devices work and what their effects are. {{cite news|first=David |last=Hambling |title=Can Strobe Weapons Really Make You Puke? |url=http://blog.wired.com/defense/2008/05/strobe-weapons.html |work=wired.com |date=May 14, 2008 |accessdate=2009-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421032307/http://blog.wired.com/defense/2008/05/strobe-weapons.html |archivedate=April 21, 2009 |df= }} ==Criticism== Some critics have questioned the desirability of developing and deploying such a device for border security use. Deborah Notkin, president of the American Immigration Lawyers Association said: "It gives me pause, particularly in regards to Mexico. Mexico is a very important economic partner of ours. I would imagine that Mexico wouldn't be particularly happy with us using a device that would be more appropriate for criminals, not just for people trying to get across the border who are looking for better opportunities. " In regards to the statement above it must also be noted that people entering the United States illegally are criminals. Peter Herby, head of the legal division of the "mines-arms unit" at the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]], suggests that such a device may raise many of the same issues as have arisen with laser-based blinding weapons, known as "[[Dazzler (weapon)|dazzler]]s" because of the intense light with which they temporarily or permanently blind people. He also raises the issue of a possible black market in such weapons. "Once they're in the hands of bad guys are the police going to have to wear protective gear to prevent them[selves] from being dazzled?" Herby states that he is not familiar with this specific device. However Lieberman of IOS says: "We're taking great care to make sure the intensities we're using fall within eye-safe limit. We're doing medically supervised tests." ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Sample |title=The latest in the war on terror: the puke saber |url=http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/science/2007/08/the_latest_in_the_war_on_terro.html |work=Guardian Unlimited -- Science section |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited |date=August 7, 2007 |accessdate=2007-08-08 }} *{{cite web |url=http://blog.wired.com/27bstroke6/2007/07/homeland-secu-3.html |title=Homeland Security Funds LED Light Saber |accessdate=2007-08-08 |last=By Singel |first=Ryan |date= July 26, 2007 |work=Threat Level: Privicy, Security, and Crime Online |publisher=Wired Online (CondéNet, Inc)|quote=THREAT LEVEL can only wonder how long will it be until war protesters and Rio Grande swimmers start wearing reflective clothing?}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080723110013/http://www.homelandsecurity.org/snapshots/newsletter/2007-07.htm#sick www.homelandsecurity.org] *{{cite web |url=http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PALL&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.htm&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=7180426.PN.&OS=PN/7180426&RS=PN/7180426 |title=United States Patent 7,180,426 (without images)}} *{{cite web |url=https://patents.google.com/patent/US7180426/en |title=United States Patent 7,180,426 (via Google, with images)}} [[Category:Modern weapons]] [[Category:Non-lethal weapons]] [[Category:Directed-energy weapons]] [[Category:Weapons of the United States]]
